title: Central banks are losing the inflation battle
text:
But Mr Aird said another disappointment was unlikely to prompt the Reserve Bank to cut interest rates as soon as next month, "given the latest employment report was reasonable and the RBA cut the cash rate in October".

"It would take a significant CPI undershoot for financial markets to price a November cut as more likely than not," he said. Market pricing for a one- quarter of a percentage point rate cash rate reduction to 0.5 per cent in November stands at just 20 per cent.

Greater conviction surrounds the Fed, with markets pricing in a 93 per cent chance of another 25 basis point cut to the Fed funds rate. That would reduce it to a range of between 1.50 and 1.75 per cent.

John Woods, Credit Suisse's chief investment officer for the Asia-Pacific, agreed and said markets would focus on the tone of the Fed's statement.

"We don't believe there will be further cuts going forward this cycle but we don't think the Fed will switch to an immediately hawkish bias," he said.

Matt Merritt, manager of multi-asset strategy at Insight Investment, said that "while inflation is notable by its absence, policy keeps on getting skewed to try and keep this expansion phase chugging along".

The Fed has hit its inflation target exactly twice in the last 10 years, he said, and only achieved that through a rare positive confluence of factors.

"The rest of the time they are way below it, so the active debate – certainly at the Federal Reserve – is what on earth do they have to do to avoid the threat of deflation coming back?"

Advertisement

Markets were intensely focused on deflation just after the global financial crisis, when the world's central banks directed their policy tools on trying to avoid negative prices.

But despite the best efforts from central bankers who have "thrown the kitchen sink at it", inflation hasn't improved, Mr Merritt said. "That's the challenge. Everyone is scratching their heads."

Central bankers may be fighting a battle that they just won't be able to win. Mr Merritt, who manages $US12 billion ($17.5 billion) at Insight, noted that, broadly, inflation has been steadily declining since the 1980s.

"Central bankers would like to say it's because they have done a really good job, but realistically there are a huge number of powerful forces such as technology and globalisation that seem to have anchored inflation at much lower levels," he said.

"Over recent decades, economic cycles have generally become longer. Part of the story is simply that inflation appears to have structurally declined."

However, he said that due to a long but subdued global economic expansion, output gaps may have taken longer to close than previously. "Maybe all the economic relationships still exist but the lags are longer."

Mark Burgess, the former head of the Future Fund and adviser to Jamieson Coote Bonds, said there was a now generation of people who think about inflation differently.

“The 1970s were extremely difficult and I mention that just because our starting point in the last 35 years was from a very tough place," he said. "And we’ve really spent 35 years driving bond yields down as we’ve changed our perception about the 1970s.”

Every time the economy strengthened, people perceived inflation would come back, and that fed through to the performance of the bond market, Mr Burgess said. In fact, “inflation doesn’t come back that often”, he said.
description: The RBA is set for another unwelcome reminder that it's losing the battle to restore price growth to the target band.
